feed.title: Susan Pan
feed.subtitle: I created this blog to document my career journey from Pharmacist to Software Engineering. I hope to solidify my learning and to also develop my written communication skills through writing technical posts about web development.

entry.title: Custom bullet styles using Fontawesome
entry.content:
This short tutorial will show you how to create custom bullet points without using the list-style-image CSS property.

  1. set list-style-type of ul to ‚Äònone‚Äô 
    ul {
 list-style-type: none;
}
  2. Create ::before pseudo-element for li. These properties are compulsory! 
    li::before {
 content: "\f005";
 font-family: "Font Awesome 5 Free";
}

    content is the Unicode of the icon on fontawesome, and remember to add the backward slash. font-family is also needed - it will show up as an empty square if it‚Äôs not included. There are only two different font-families in the free plan: ‚ÄúFont Awesome 5 Free‚Äù and ‚ÄúFont Awesome 5 Brands‚Äù so make sure to change it if you are using brand logos. If you are on the Pro Plan, the official documentation lists the different font-families available.

  3. Add these optional properties to make it prettier. 
    li::before {
 padding-right: 8px;
 color: yellow;
 font-weight: 600;
}

    font-weight: for some of the icons, adding ‚Äò600‚Äô as the font-weight will fill in the icon

If you‚Äôd like to learn about this in more detail, have a look at the official font-awesome documentation page.
entry.summary: This short tutorial will show you how to create custom bullet points without using the list-style-image CSS property.

entry.title: Welcome 2021!
entry.content:
Happy new year!! It‚Äôs finally 2021, and it could not have come any sooner. I think I can confidently speak for all of us when I say 2020 was a bit of a sht-show.

I might start off with a mini retrospective of 2020, but I‚Äôll try not to dwell. Collectively, 2020 was a really horrible year, but there were a few small wins that I can celebrate and I hope you‚Äôll take some time to think about yours as well.

  • My direct family and extended family have all stayed healthy during the year
  • I was able to be there for and provide emotional support to some of my friends who were going through some difficult times
  • I made the decision to pursue a career in software development and am incredibly lucky to have been able to attend a full-time bootcamp to upskill
  • I met such supportive teachers and fellow students at my bootcamp, but unfortunately still haven‚Äôt been able to meet them in person as I‚Äôm in a different city :(
  • Was able to finally attend yoga classes and have been practising pretty consistently after wanting to for the longest time

It could just be the holiday season, but I‚Äôve been so thankful for being able to see and have genuine, in-person connections with my close friends and family. To anyone who is still waiting to see their loved ones, hold on a little longer! It will get better.

Let‚Äôs put these bittersweet memories of 2020 to rest, and welcome the new year. Here‚Äôs to 2021 - the year that we‚Äôll all be cultivating the energy to accomplish great things. To everyone who is reading, studying, hustling or building projects to become a better developer, this year will bring great success. Whether you‚Äôre looking to create a start-up, to finally land that first developer role or for those of you who are taking a break to extinguish the possibility of burnout, I‚Äôm rooting for you!

We‚Äôre ready for you, 2021. Bring it on!
entry.summary: Happy new year!! It‚Äôs finally 2021, and it could not have come any sooner. I think I can confidently speak for all of us when I say 2020 was a bit of a sht-show.

entry.title: My first blog post!
entry.content:
Welcome to my blog! I‚Äôve created this so that I have my own corner of the internet to write about all the things I‚Äôve learnt about tech. I‚Äôm hoping to use this platform as a way for me to really bring home the core software engineering concepts while also practising my written communication.

Most of the posts I create will be to document my progress on side-projects, my career journey or technical posts for new concepts that I come across. Although I‚Äôm only at the very beginning of my tech career, I hope there will be some things that you can learn from my posts!

Thanks for taking the time to read this! Feel free to stay and have a little poke around, but don‚Äôt forget to take a break and have a quick stretch before you continue :)
entry.summary: Welcome to my blog! I‚Äôve created this so that I have my own corner of the internet to write about all the things I‚Äôve learnt about tech.

entry.title: Creating my first blog with Jekyll

link.title: Creating my first blog with Jekyll

entry.content:
Jekyll is a framework that makes creating static websites super simple. A static website is one where there isn‚Äôt too much server-side programming. These types of websites don‚Äôt need the in-depth, extensive network of heavier frameworks such as Ruby on Rails. Some examples include:

  • Blogs
  • Company websites
  • Micro-sites
  • Educational websites

As I jumped from Rails to Jekyll, the installation and syntax was relatively straight-forward - I didn‚Äôt bump into any obstacles until I tried using some of the jekyll gems - but more on that later. If you‚Äôre just beginning, the Jekyll documentation is superb. Everything is explained well with great examples to follow. If you get stuck, look there first!
entry.summary: Jekyll is a framework that makes creating static websites super simple. A static website is one where there isn‚Äôt too much server-side programming.
